message: Great! Based on your answers, I'll create the automation. Confidence: 57%

suggestions.description: Every 15 minutes, if the Office Samsung TV is ON and your Office WLED light (not listed in entities, assumed existing) is ON, a script snapshot/restores its state, then applies a fully random WLED effect (random effect, palette, colors, and brightness 100%) for 15 seconds, and finally restores the exact previous state. This directly follows your intent: Office Samsung TV power is the gatekeeper; the effect only runs when the WLED is already ON (your answer to Q2), and the randomization covers effect and colors/palette (your answer to Q3). Because the WLED entity itself is not in the provided entity list, this automation focuses its logic around the Office Samsung TV as the controlling condition and assumes you’ll plug in the correct WLED light entity_id where indicated.
trigger_summary: Time pattern trigger: every 15 minutes (e.g., */15 in minutes field).
Condition: Office Samsung TV power state must be ON.
Condition: WLED light must already be ON (so the effect never turns it on).
action_summary: 1) Call a WLED-specific snapshot service (from the WLED integration or light/snapshot script) to store the current state of the WLED light (power, brightness, color, effect, palette, etc.).
2) Call a WLED service (e.g., wled.effect or light.turn_on with WLED attributes) to set: random effect, random palette/colors, and brightness to 100%.
3) Wait exactly 15 seconds.
4) Call the corresponding restore service (e.g., wled.preset, light/restore, or your own snapshot/restore script) to return the WLED to its exact pre-effect state.
devices_involved: Hue outdoor motion sensor 1 Motion sensor enabled
Hue outdoor motion sensor 1 Light sensor enabled

debug.system_prompt:
You are a HIGHLY CREATIVE and experienced Home Assistant automation expert with deep knowledge of device capabilities and smart home best practices.

Your expertise includes:
- Understanding device-specific features (LED notifications, smart modes, timers, color control, etc.)
- Creating practical, safe, and user-friendly automations
- Leveraging manufacturer-specific capabilities for creative solutions
- Considering device health and reliability in recommendations
- Designing sophisticated automation sequences and patterns

CRITICAL: When clarification context is provided (questions and answers), you MUST:
- Use the EXACT devices, locations, and preferences specified in the clarification answers
- Prioritize user-selected entities over generic assumptions
- Respect all user choices and selections - they override your initial interpretations
- If the user specified "all four lights in office", find and use exactly those four lights
- Never substitute different devices than what the user explicitly selected or confirmed

ADVANCED CAPABILITY EXAMPLES:

Numeric Capabilities (with ranges):
- Brightness (0-100%): "Fade lights to 50% brightness over 5 seconds"
- Color Temperature (153-500K): "Warm from 500K to 300K over 10 minutes"
- Timer (1-80 seconds): "Set fan timer to 30 seconds"
- Position (0-100%): "Move blinds to 75% position"

Enum Capabilities (with values):
- Speed [off, low, medium, high]: "Set fan to medium speed when temperature > 75F"
- Mode [auto, manual, schedule]: "Switch to manual mode when motion detected"
- State [ON, OFF]: "Turn on when door opens"

Composite Capabilities (with features):
- Breeze Mode {speed1, time1, speed2, time2}: "Configure fan to run high for 30s, then low for 15s"
- LED Notifications {state, brightness}: "Flash red at 80% brightness for 3 seconds"
- Fan Control {speed, oscillate}: "Set oscillating fan to high speed"

Binary Capabilities:
- LED Notifications (ON/OFF): "Flash LED when door opens"
- Power State (ON/OFF): "Toggle device when condition met"

Guidelines:
- Use device friendly names, not entity IDs in descriptions
- Leverage ACTUAL capability types, ranges, and values from device intelligence
- Use capability properties (min/max, enum values) for precise automations
- Consider device health scores (prioritize devices with health_score > 70, avoid devices with health_score < 50)
- Keep automations simple, practical, and easy to understand
- Always include proper service calls and valid Home Assistant syntax
- Be creative and think beyond basic on/off patterns
- Create sophisticated sequences using composite capabilities
- Use numeric ranges for smooth transitions and graduated effects
- Leverage enum values for state-specific automations

openai_response.description: Every 15 minutes, if the Office Samsung TV is ON and your Office WLED light (not listed in entities, assumed existing) is ON, a script snapshot/restores its state, then applies a fully random WLED effect (random effect, palette, colors, and brightness 100%) for 15 seconds, and finally restores the exact previous state. This directly follows your intent: Office Samsung TV power is the gatekeeper; the effect only runs when the WLED is already ON (your answer to Q2), and the randomization covers effect and colors/palette (your answer to Q3). Because the WLED entity itself is not in the provided entity list, this automation focuses its logic around the Office Samsung TV as the controlling condition and assumes you’ll plug in the correct WLED light entity_id where indicated.
trigger_summary: Time pattern trigger: every 15 minutes (e.g., */15 in minutes field).
Condition: Office Samsung TV power state must be ON.
Condition: WLED light must already be ON (so the effect never turns it on).
action_summary: 1) Call a WLED-specific snapshot service (from the WLED integration or light/snapshot script) to store the current state of the WLED light (power, brightness, color, effect, palette, etc.).
2) Call a WLED service (e.g., wled.effect or light.turn_on with WLED attributes) to set: random effect, random palette/colors, and brightness to 100%.
3) Wait exactly 15 seconds.
4) Call the corresponding restore service (e.g., wled.preset, light/restore, or your own snapshot/restore script) to return the WLED to its exact pre-effect state.

openai_response.description: Building on the basic randomized effect, this enhanced version turns the Office WLED effect into a subtle ‘ambient pulse’ that keys off the Office Samsung TV being ON, while also visually echoing the office environment using your two known office lights: Office Front Left and Office Back Right. Every 15 minutes, if the TV and the WLED are ON, the automation snapshots the WLED, chooses a random WLED effect/palette at 100% brightness for 15 seconds, then restores the exact previous WLED state. During those 15 seconds, Office Front Left and Office Back Right briefly and gently mirror the mood: they fade up slightly and shift toward a soft, warm color, then smoothly fade back to their original values. This keeps the WLED as the star, but adds a room-wide ‘breathing’ feel without changing anything permanently.
trigger_summary: Condition: Office Samsung TV power state must be ON.
Condition: WLED light must already be ON before running the effect.
action_summary: 1) Snapshot WLED state (brightness, colors, effect, palette, power) via a WLED or snapshot script.
2) Snapshot Office Front Left and Office Back Right (brightness, color_temp/rgb_color, effect) using a light snapshot helper/blueprint.
3) Set WLED to a random effect and random palette/colors at 100% brightness.
4) In parallel, gently increase brightness of Office Front Left and Office Back Right by a small amount (e.g., +20–30%) and nudge their color toward a warm, cozy tint (using rgb_color or color_temp).
5) Wait 15 seconds while the WLED runs its randomized effect and the office lights sit in the slightly brighter, warmer state.
6) Restore WLED to its exact snapshot state.
7) Restore Office Front Left and Office Back Right to their snapshot states so the office returns precisely to how it was before the pulse.

clarification_context.original_query: Every 15 mins choose a random effect on the Office WLED device. Play the effect for 15 secs. Choose random effect, random colors and brightness to 100%. At the end of the 15 sec the WLED light needs to return to exactly what it was before it started.

questions_and_answers.question: Which device should this WLED effect automation control? I don’t see a clearly named WLED light in your devices list. Is it one of these, or a different light entity that isn’t shown here?
questions_and_answers.answer: Use Office Samsung TV power state

questions_and_answers.question: When you say brightness to 100%, do you want the automation to always force the WLED brightness to 100% during the 15-second effect, even if it was dimmer before, and then restore the original brightness afterward?
questions_and_answers.answer: Only run the effect when the WLED light is already ON

questions_and_answers.question: For the random effect itself, do you want to avoid repeating the same effect back-to-back (i.e., always pick a different effect than the previous one if possible), or is it fine if the same effect is randomly chosen twice in a row?
questions_and_answers.answer: Randomize all available WLED colors/palette for the effect

conversation_history.original_query: Every 15 mins choose a random effect on the Office WLED device. Play the effect for 15 secs. Choose random effect, random colors and brightness to 100%. At the end of the 15 sec the WLED light needs to return to exactly what it was before it started.

questions.question_text: Which device should this WLED effect automation control? I don’t see a clearly named WLED light in your devices list. Is it one of these, or a different light entity that isn’t shown here?

When you say brightness to 100%, do you want the automation to always force the WLED brightness to 100% during the 15-second effect, even if it was dimmer before, and then restore the original brightness afterward?
When you say “every 15 minutes”, do you want this to run 24/7, or only during certain hours (for example, only in the evenings or only when you’re typically in the office)?
Should the random effect only run when the office is actually in use (for example, when presence is detected or when the Office Samsung TV is on), or should it run regardless of presence/activity?

For the random effect itself, do you want to avoid repeating the same effect back-to-back (i.e., always pick a different effect than the previous one if possible), or is it fine if the same effect is randomly chosen twice in a row?
Which entity should we use to detect presence in the office for this automation (for example, the Presence-Sensor-FP2-8B8A, the Office Samsung TV being on, or something else)?

If the WLED light is OFF when presence is detected and the 15‑minute timer hits, should the automation temporarily turn it ON to run the 15‑second random effect, or only run the effect when the light is already on?

When you say random colors, do you want the automation to randomize all available color slots/palettes for the chosen WLED effect, or just pick a single random solid color for the whole strip during the 15‑second effect?

answers.answer_text: Use Office Samsung TV power state
Only run the effect when the WLED light is already ON
Randomize all available WLED colors/palette for the effect

suggestions.description: Building on the basic randomized effect, this enhanced version turns the Office WLED effect into a subtle ‘ambient pulse’ that keys off the Office Samsung TV being ON, while also visually echoing the office environment using your two known office lights: Office Front Left and Office Back Right. Every 15 minutes, if the TV and the WLED are ON, the automation snapshots the WLED, chooses a random WLED effect/palette at 100% brightness for 15 seconds, then restores the exact previous WLED state. During those 15 seconds, Office Front Left and Office Back Right briefly and gently mirror the mood: they fade up slightly and shift toward a soft, warm color, then smoothly fade back to their original values. This keeps the WLED as the star, but adds a room-wide ‘breathing’ feel without changing anything permanently.
trigger_summary: Condition: Office Samsung TV power state must be ON.
Condition: WLED light must already be ON before running the effect.
action_summary: 1) Snapshot WLED state (brightness, colors, effect, palette, power) via a WLED or snapshot script.
2) Snapshot Office Front Left and Office Back Right (brightness, color_temp/rgb_color, effect) using a light snapshot helper/blueprint.
3) Set WLED to a random effect and random palette/colors at 100% brightness.
4) In parallel, gently increase brightness of Office Front Left and Office Back Right by a small amount (e.g., +20–30%) and nudge their color toward a warm, cozy tint (using rgb_color or color_temp).
5) Wait 15 seconds while the WLED runs its randomized effect and the office lights sit in the slightly brighter, warmer state.
6) Restore WLED to its exact snapshot state.
7) Restore Office Front Left and Office Back Right to their snapshot states so the office returns precisely to how it was before the pulse.
devices_involved: Hue outdoor motion sensor 1 Motion sensor enabled
Hue outdoor motion sensor 1 Light sensor enabled

debug.system_prompt:
You are a HIGHLY CREATIVE and experienced Home Assistant automation expert with deep knowledge of device capabilities and smart home best practices.

Your expertise includes:
- Understanding device-specific features (LED notifications, smart modes, timers, color control, etc.)
- Creating practical, safe, and user-friendly automations
- Leveraging manufacturer-specific capabilities for creative solutions
- Considering device health and reliability in recommendations
- Designing sophisticated automation sequences and patterns

CRITICAL: When clarification context is provided (questions and answers), you MUST:
- Use the EXACT devices, locations, and preferences specified in the clarification answers
- Prioritize user-selected entities over generic assumptions
- Respect all user choices and selections - they override your initial interpretations
- If the user specified "all four lights in office", find and use exactly those four lights
- Never substitute different devices than what the user explicitly selected or confirmed

ADVANCED CAPABILITY EXAMPLES:

Numeric Capabilities (with ranges):
- Brightness (0-100%): "Fade lights to 50% brightness over 5 seconds"
- Color Temperature (153-500K): "Warm from 500K to 300K over 10 minutes"
- Timer (1-80 seconds): "Set fan timer to 30 seconds"
- Position (0-100%): "Move blinds to 75% position"

Enum Capabilities (with values):
- Speed [off, low, medium, high]: "Set fan to medium speed when temperature > 75F"
- Mode [auto, manual, schedule]: "Switch to manual mode when motion detected"
- State [ON, OFF]: "Turn on when door opens"

Composite Capabilities (with features):
- Breeze Mode {speed1, time1, speed2, time2}: "Configure fan to run high for 30s, then low for 15s"
- LED Notifications {state, brightness}: "Flash red at 80% brightness for 3 seconds"
- Fan Control {speed, oscillate}: "Set oscillating fan to high speed"

Binary Capabilities:
- LED Notifications (ON/OFF): "Flash LED when door opens"
- Power State (ON/OFF): "Toggle device when condition met"

Guidelines:
- Use device friendly names, not entity IDs in descriptions
- Leverage ACTUAL capability types, ranges, and values from device intelligence
- Use capability properties (min/max, enum values) for precise automations
- Consider device health scores (prioritize devices with health_score > 70, avoid devices with health_score < 50)
- Keep automations simple, practical, and easy to understand
- Always include proper service calls and valid Home Assistant syntax
- Be creative and think beyond basic on/off patterns
- Create sophisticated sequences using composite capabilities
- Use numeric ranges for smooth transitions and graduated effects
- Leverage enum values for state-specific automations

CREATIVE FLOURISH

openai_response.description: Every 15 minutes, if the Office Samsung TV is ON and your Office WLED light (not listed in entities, assumed existing) is ON, a script snapshot/restores its state, then applies a fully random WLED effect (random effect, palette, colors, and brightness 100%) for 15 seconds, and finally restores the exact previous state. This directly follows your intent: Office Samsung TV power is the gatekeeper; the effect only runs when the WLED is already ON (your answer to Q2), and the randomization covers effect and colors/palette (your answer to Q3). Because the WLED entity itself is not in the provided entity list, this automation focuses its logic around the Office Samsung TV as the controlling condition and assumes you’ll plug in the correct WLED light entity_id where indicated.
trigger_summary: Time pattern trigger: every 15 minutes (e.g., */15 in minutes field).
Condition: Office Samsung TV power state must be ON.
Condition: WLED light must already be ON (so the effect never turns it on).
action_summary: 1) Call a WLED-specific snapshot service (from the WLED integration or light/snapshot script) to store the current state of the WLED light (power, brightness, color, effect, palette, etc.).
2) Call a WLED service (e.g., wled.effect or light.turn_on with WLED attributes) to set: random effect, random palette/colors, and brightness to 100%.
3) Wait exactly 15 seconds.
4) Call the corresponding restore service (e.g., wled.preset, light/restore, or your own snapshot/restore script) to return the WLED to its exact pre-effect state.

openai_response.description: Building on the basic randomized effect, this enhanced version turns the Office WLED effect into a subtle ‘ambient pulse’ that keys off the Office Samsung TV being ON, while also visually echoing the office environment using your two known office lights: Office Front Left and Office Back Right. Every 15 minutes, if the TV and the WLED are ON, the automation snapshots the WLED, chooses a random WLED effect/palette at 100% brightness for 15 seconds, then restores the exact previous WLED state. During those 15 seconds, Office Front Left and Office Back Right briefly and gently mirror the mood: they fade up slightly and shift toward a soft, warm color, then smoothly fade back to their original values. This keeps the WLED as the star, but adds a room-wide ‘breathing’ feel without changing anything permanently.
trigger_summary: Condition: Office Samsung TV power state must be ON.
Condition: WLED light must already be ON before running the effect.
action_summary: 1) Snapshot WLED state (brightness, colors, effect, palette, power) via a WLED or snapshot script.
2) Snapshot Office Front Left and Office Back Right (brightness, color_temp/rgb_color, effect) using a light snapshot helper/blueprint.
3) Set WLED to a random effect and random palette/colors at 100% brightness.
4) In parallel, gently increase brightness of Office Front Left and Office Back Right by a small amount (e.g., +20–30%) and nudge their color toward a warm, cozy tint (using rgb_color or color_temp).
5) Wait 15 seconds while the WLED runs its randomized effect and the office lights sit in the slightly brighter, warmer state.
6) Restore WLED to its exact snapshot state.
7) Restore Office Front Left and Office Back Right to their snapshot states so the office returns precisely to how it was before the pulse.

clarification_context.original_query: Every 15 mins choose a random effect on the Office WLED device. Play the effect for 15 secs. Choose random effect, random colors and brightness to 100%. At the end of the 15 sec the WLED light needs to return to exactly what it was before it started.

questions_and_answers.question: Which device should this WLED effect automation control? I don’t see a clearly named WLED light in your devices list. Is it one of these, or a different light entity that isn’t shown here?
questions_and_answers.answer: Use Office Samsung TV power state

questions_and_answers.question: When you say brightness to 100%, do you want the automation to always force the WLED brightness to 100% during the 15-second effect, even if it was dimmer before, and then restore the original brightness afterward?
questions_and_answers.answer: Only run the effect when the WLED light is already ON

questions_and_answers.question: For the random effect itself, do you want to avoid repeating the same effect back-to-back (i.e., always pick a different effect than the previous one if possible), or is it fine if the same effect is randomly chosen twice in a row?
questions_and_answers.answer: Randomize all available WLED colors/palette for the effect

conversation_history.original_query: Every 15 mins choose a random effect on the Office WLED device. Play the effect for 15 secs. Choose random effect, random colors and brightness to 100%. At the end of the 15 sec the WLED light needs to return to exactly what it was before it started.

questions.question_text: Which device should this WLED effect automation control? I don’t see a clearly named WLED light in your devices list. Is it one of these, or a different light entity that isn’t shown here?

When you say brightness to 100%, do you want the automation to always force the WLED brightness to 100% during the 15-second effect, even if it was dimmer before, and then restore the original brightness afterward?
When you say “every 15 minutes”, do you want this to run 24/7, or only during certain hours (for example, only in the evenings or only when you’re typically in the office)?
Should the random effect only run when the office is actually in use (for example, when presence is detected or when the Office Samsung TV is on), or should it run regardless of presence/activity?

For the random effect itself, do you want to avoid repeating the same effect back-to-back (i.e., always pick a different effect than the previous one if possible), or is it fine if the same effect is randomly chosen twice in a row?
Which entity should we use to detect presence in the office for this automation (for example, the Presence-Sensor-FP2-8B8A, the Office Samsung TV being on, or something else)?

If the WLED light is OFF when presence is detected and the 15‑minute timer hits, should the automation temporarily turn it ON to run the 15‑second random effect, or only run the effect when the light is already on?

When you say random colors, do you want the automation to randomize all available color slots/palettes for the chosen WLED effect, or just pick a single random solid color for the whole strip during the 15‑second effect?

answers.answer_text: Use Office Samsung TV power state
Only run the effect when the WLED light is already ON
Randomize all available WLED colors/palette for the effect

Original request: Every 15 mins choose a random effect on the Office WLED device. Play the effect for 15 secs. Choose random effect, random colors and brightness to 100%. At the end of the 15 sec the WLED light needs to return to exactly what it was before it started.

Clarifications provided:
  • Use Office Samsung TV power state
  • Only run the effect when the WLED light is already ON
  • Randomize all available WLED colors/palette for the effect
